intro: Otocarpus, commonly known as the sea hibiscus, is a genus of flowering plants in the mallow family. It is characterized by its woody, shrub-like structure and succulent leaves that help it retain water in coastal environments. The flowers are typically showy, with five petals and a prominent central stamen, often in shades of yellow or orange. Otocarpus species are native to tropical regions of the Americas and are commonly found in sandy or coastal soils. These plants are adapted to salt spray and can thrive in harsh maritime conditions.
